objdescid.compdate: 1786The dating is based on stylistic considerations and the relationship, as an alternative design, to Blake's engraving in Thomas Commins, *An Elegy Set to Music* (1786).

objinfo.medium: pencil, pen and ink, monochrome wash

provenance.name: Collection of Robert N. Essick
provenance.note: Probably inherited by Blake's wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; probably acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, in lot 170 with five other works by Blake (14s. to the dealer H. Toovey); Henry Cunliffe, sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 11 May 1895, lot 105 (16s. to the dealer Frederick Keppel); an American private collection; on consignment with Salander-O'Reilly Galleries, New York, no later than Dec. 1995; acquired Jan. 1996 by Robert N. Essick, with Blake's wash drawing, *An Encounter in Heaven*, for $27,500 for both drawings.

desc.objtitle:
Alternative Design for Commins's "Elegy",
Object 1 (Butlin WBA2)

objnote.p: This is an alternative preliminary design for the etching/engraving, designed and engraved by Blake, for Thomas Commins, *An Elegy Set to Music* (1786). The recto of this monochrome wash drawing includes another alternative preliminary wash drawing for Commins (see Object 46). The discovery (or rediscovery) of this wash drawing was announced in Martin Butlin, "Two Newly Identified Sketches for Thomas Commins's *An Elegy* and Further Rediscovered Drawings of the 1780s," *Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly*, 26.1 (summer 1992): 21-26. The pen and ink inscriptions on this drawing were probably written by Henry Cunliffe no earlier than 1862.
The inscriptions at the bottom of the leaf read "Purchased at Sothebys in a Lot / 28. Apr. 1862 / A Sketch by William Blake. / Obit 12 Aug. 1828 / For a Biog.y of B. see Cunninghams British Painters"

illustration.illusobjdesc: This wash drawing depicts a male figure rowing a boat. His body faces left, but he leans back and twists so that his torso faces the viewer and his head looks to the right. His left arm bends at the elbow and his left leg is bent at the knee, both at ninety-degree angles. His right arm and leg extend outward, with both bent slightly at forty-five degree angles. He holds an oar in each hand, although only the top halves are visible. The bottom halves appear to be submerged in the water. He has short curly hair and wears a tunic that appears to be open at the chest. He rows the boat in a river, lake, or other body or water. A shore or bank appears near the boat to the right, or it may be a large rock. A large leafy tree, or perhaps several smaller leafy trees, appears in the background. The wash area below the tree trunks may be a hill or patch of grass. There are several indeterminate, light sketch marks in the lower right corner.

component.illusobjdesc: This wash drawing depicts a male figure rowing a boat. His body faces left, but he leans back and twists so that his torso faces the viewer and his head looks to the right. His left arm bends at the elbow and his left leg is bent at the knee, both at ninety-degree angles. His right arm and leg extend outward, with both bent slightly at forty-five degree angles. He holds an oar in each hand, although only the top halves are visible. The bottom halves appear to be submerged in the water. He has short curly hair and wears a tunic that appears to be open at the chest.
The figure sits in a boat and holds an oar in each hand. Only the top halves of the oars are visible. The bottom halves appear to be submerged in the water.
The figure rows the boat in a river, lake, or other body or water.
A shore or bank appears near the boat to the right. It may also be a large rock.
A large leafy tree, or perhaps several smaller leafy trees, appears in the background. The wash area below the tree trunks may be a hill or patch of grass.
There are several indeterminate, light sketch marks in the lower right corner.
